A large part of the sell off in SKX was based on an increase in expenses, but the thought pattern that this was a "concern" is not sound. SKX reported a 24% increase in expenses, which was an additional $73 M jump in G&A, but this included $37.4 M to support international growth and $18.3 M for operating 73 additional company owned stores, of which 15 new ones opened during the first quarter. Additionally, selling expenses climbed $10.6 M due mostly to higher international advertising expenses. By my way of looking at it, all of those added expenses will produce added growth, especially in foreign markets where the potential for growth appears to be greatest. There is no reason to fret about a well funded and well running company, that has show it can consistently achieve growth, spending some funds where they believe it is going to achieve benefits. They are not going into debt or taking on interest obligations. It is a management judgment call and not cause for a 36% wipe out of valuation. Rather it is cause to expect growth will be promoted and will continue. Sometimes the analysts just fret over things that are off base, and I believe this is one of those cases. When you look at all the other shoe companies, following the haircut that the analysts gave SKX, I suggest it is the best relative value out there. Most of the charts show this group is really doing very well, and I continue to argue that SKX makes good shoes, that are quite popular and they are growing their position in the marketplace. Right now, the PPS is oversold and undervalued in my opinion, and I am not worried about the 1st quarter increase in the expenses, so long as they achieve the desired effects. If the 2nd quarter beats the guidance or comes in at the high side of the range, I think there will be a very rapid recovery. In the meantime, it is starting to look like the selling is exhausted, the recent bottom is in, and SKX has plenty of room to move up if the institutions come to the obvious conclusion that SKX is in a hot group of footwear stocks, and has a really nice risk/reward ratio down here. Will it retest the recent lows, or jump on an improvement in sentiment. Look at the numbers and make up your own mind, but I think it is a strong buy right here at $30.46. For those technically inclined, take a look at the Bollinger bands which is another way to look at the volatility and try to project where it might head next. Another consideration is that even the analysts have 7 strong buys and only one sell on SKX so they know it is not overpriced. Please do your own due diligence to evaluate your investments or trades, and never rely on chat board commentary alone.

The Zacks Rank favors stocks that have recently seen positive revisions to their earnings estimates, so investors should rest assured that SKX has an improving earnings outlook. However, value investors will care about much more than just this.Value investors analyze a variety of traditional, tried-and-true metrics to help find companies that they believe are undervalued at their current share price levels.Our Value category highlights undervalued companies by looking at a variety of key metrics, including the popular P/E ratio, as well as the P/S ratio, earnings yield, cash flow per share, and a variety of other fundamentals that have been used by value investors for years.SKX currently has a forward P/E ratio of 14.54, while NKE has a forward P/E of 28.12. We also note that SKX has a PEG ratio of 0.97. This popular figure is similar to the widely-used P/E ratio, but the PEG ratio also considers a company's expected EPS growth rate. NKE currently has a PEG ratio of 2.16.Another notable valuation metric for SKX is its P/B ratio of 2.17. The P/B ratio is used to compare a stock's market value with its book value, which is defined as total assets minus total liabilities. For comparison, NKE has a P/B of 14.20.These are just a few of the metrics contributing to SKX's Value grade of A and NKE's Value grade of F.SKX is currently sporting an improving earnings outlook, which makes it stick out in our Zacks Rank model.
